text: hello
everybody thank you for coming to our
talk today so my name is Anil and I'm
with uh a company called overclock Labs
that is the company behind Akash Network
which is the op source project we're
going to talk about today and then with
me is Logan from a startup called tamper
AI that is one of the most active users
of Akash so um so what we're going to do
today we have about 15 minutes for this
talk so what what I want to do is
obviously show you all how you can use
Ray with Akash uh for training and other
things and so we'll do two things we'll
try to show you a demo of deploying a
ray cluster on Akash and hopefully do
that in a couple of minutes uh but I'd
also like to have Logan talk about how
he's used Ray on Akash specifically to
do some AI model training uh but before
we get to that I want to give you a
quick overview of what Akash is because
I assume most people here are hearing
about us for the first time and then at
the end I'm going to have something uh
interesting hopefully for people that
are from startups or from small teams
over here so let's dig in uh with a
quick with a quick overview of Akash
Network so uh to understand Akash a
little bit uh just a quick review of
public Cloud the public Cloud Model
today so obviously in the public Cloud
Model today you have infrastructure
that's owned by a single entity like AWS
for example and um you have a bunch of
users that connect to that
infrastructure and this model obviously
has worked really well for the last 20
years uh primarily because it has
enabled a huge amount of innovation for
startups uh so if you think back to back
when before the cloud existed if you
were a startup trying to build something
new uh you had to put a huge amount of
money in terms of capital expenditure up
front and that was a huge barrier to
entry for startups and that kind of
killed a lot of the innovation that
could have happened uh cloud enabled
startups to be able to go and spin up
you know their services without having
to put that huge amount of capex up
front and it's been extremely helpful in
terms of driving Innovation so I guess
the question then is why are we trying
to change uh the existing cloud model
with Akash which you know is what I'm
going to talk about so there's kind of
two things I want to bring to your
attention the first is even though there
exist these really big public clouds in
the world today uh there still are a
huge number of data centers across the
world so depending on who you talk to
there's anywhere from a few hundred to
several thousands of data centers
distributed across the world and these
are all independent data centers that
have you know maybe one location or two
locations and they may have you know a
few hundred or a few thousand servers on
average most of these data centers we
have spoken to a lot of them and most of
them tell us that they only end up
utilizing about 20% of the server
capacity that they have and the
remaining 60 70 80% gets either
underutilized or not utilized at all on
a daily basis and so what we figured is
if there's a way for us to make all that
server capacity available to folks that
need it we can realize some gains on
both sides of that equation uh so that's
one aspect of it the other aspect is in
the last couple of years as AI has
become more
mainstream what has happened is that
there's been a huge amount of strain on
availability of accelerated compute AKA
gpus because there's only one vendor
producing those and so what that has
caused is that uh even at the super
hyperscaler public clouds like AWS and
gcp and Azure uh if you're a small
startup and you want to let's say use
llama 3.1 today to go and do some
inference you would need potentially 8
to 24 h100s and if you want to get those
from from these public clouds it's going
to be a problem because they would
expect you to commit to a cluster of 64
of gpus for one year and so effec you're
kind of spending a huge amount of capex
even if you're using the cloud for gpus
so that kind of disrupts the old cloud
model and brings us back to the old days
so what can we do about this so here's
what Akash has done is uh we have
basically built uh what lots of people
like to call the Airbnb for cloud
compute so what we do is we work with
data centers all across the world and
that's all the providers that you see up
there each of those think of those as a
single data center with certain amount
of capacity it may be the entire data
center it may be a portion of it and
what we build is a software layer that
sits between them and the users that
want access to that compute and um what
we're able to do in the process is uh
realize some benefits on both sides of
that equation so what do you get for
using akash you essentially get uh you
know a lot of things you get a lot of
locations in the world Akash today has
over 65 uh data centers across the world
that work with us and we're hoping to
take this into the several hundreds over
the next few years uh so that's way more
regions already than what you can see
with the public clouds but the biggest
benefit obviously is on the GPU side
which is accelerated compute on the on
the right side of the slide uh you can
get access to an h100 for example on
demand for $145 right now on on Akash
similarly you can get access to an a100
GPU for under 80 cents an hour uh on
demand again no Reserve no no need to
commit to a year no need to commit to a
64x cluster and then on the regular
compute side on average you save about
30 to 40% relative to what you can get
from AWS and you can go to the URL down
there Akash Network gpus and you can
check out both a live version of both of
these uh both of these Pages um cool so
the other aspect that's unique about
Akash that I hope a lot of the folks
here will find uh useful and interesting
because I'm assuming there's a bunch of
people that work on open source software
given that this is an open source uh
Summit is that Akash not only uses open
source software namely kubernetes and
Docker and a whole bunch of other things
um but we also so are good uh open
source citizens in that we take all of
the stuff that we have built and we open
source it so if you go to GitHub SL
Akash D Network you can literally see
every aspect of the uh of of the
essentially the services that make Akash
run all of that is open source today um
and then not only do we stop there we
actually take it one step further and uh
we actually have a 100% open development
model as well so what that means is uh
all the work that happens on our whether
it's new features whether it's
participating in events like this
whether it is you know marketing
anything all of that gets discussed in
the open uh and so what we have is a
model very similar to what you've seen
for example with the kubernetes project
where they have special interest groups
and work groups and these special
interest groups meet on a regular basis
they talk about various aspects of the
project so in our case we have special
interest groups for providers for
clients for deployments various things
right um and uh and so that's one aspect
of it and then uh you can see below uh
all the meetings that happen as part of
those special interest groups and the
steering committee which kind of guides
the overall project all of those are
also stored on on GitHub as well uh so
it's an amazing project to get involved
with um talking one level deeper because
uh I'm assuming most of the folks here
are technical I'll get a little bit into
the weeds uh this is the typical
deployment workflow that you can expect
to see on Akash um looking sort of from
the left to the right here you as a user
uh you bring your application which
could be a workload it could be an AI
inference app it could be a web service
it could be a static web page I don't
care uh you containerize that and then
you write something called an sdl file
sdl stands for stack definition language
and it's basically uh you specifying you
as an Ops engineer or a devops engineer
specifying what you think is the
resource requirements for that specific
workload so you know uh gpus CPUs memory
storage
Etc so you do that and then you submit
that to the network uh and when you do
that what happens is Akash takes your
request and it broadcasts it across all
of the providers on the network so
there's over 60 of them today uh every
single one of those providers receives
that request and it looks at it and says
hey can I uh can I fulfill the
requirements of this request and if it
can then the provider responds back with
what's called a bid and so what you see
is you see a whole bunch of bids come
back in response to your request and
then you can pick the bid that you like
based on price based on location based
on a whole bunch of attributes that each
of the provider exposes and then once
you pick a bid uh and say this is the
provider I want to choose then Akash
goes ahead and deploys your workload
onto that provider and gives you a entry
point into it and that's something that
you define as well so it could be an SSH
uh session into it it could be HTTP
endpoint it could be anything um so I
talked about sdl uh so let's look at
really quickly what the sdl file
structure is so this is what a typical
sdl file looks like this is a simple
version you can get really complicated
with this but um anybody that's done
Docker compose here should find this
very familiar but uh just to sort of
break it down a little bit there's kind
of four or five sections to this one of
the section where you specify all the
apps and services that you want to be
running you can have any number of those
um what you specify there is the
container image the ports you want to
expose you can also pass environment
variables and command line arguments to
it the next is the compute profiles for
each of the services so this is where
you specify what you need in terms of uh
compute and then below that is uh uh
information about which providers you
want to work with followed by how much
you want to pay so you can actually set
a limit and say don't show me any
providers that exceed this price right
so you can actually put a filter on that
and then the last is how many replicas
you want to run out that service so
that's the sdl file structure what I
want to do next is uh in the next five
or six minutes that I have I want to
show a demo of deploying a ray cluster
on Akash if I can do that but before I
do that I want to invite Logan to talk
about how he has used Akash with Ray for
AI
training thanks Anil um yeah so so so my
company Thumper AI we wanted to train a
Creative Commons text image model that
would be uh for artists who didn't want
to use data that had been acquired based
off training on copyrighted images and
we had a really hard time getting gpus
from large public clouds and we were
very frustrated by that and we went to a
c and we said wow like the the GPU
prices are insanely better um you know
this is sometimes like 50 sometimes like
80% less uh than what other than AWS and
and often very much cheaper than even
the the next closest but the ultimate
question is like can you run what you
really care about in the real world and
for us for our text to image Foundation

as well as Ray data and so in order to
do that we went out we went onto a Kosh
we created a 64 uh a100 GPU cluster we
used minio instead of a instead of a big
cloud provider S3 bucket and we were
able to successfully train our uh at-1
Foundation model um and and do it using
the infrastructure that exists today on
aosh um and we and we when we would have
saved a a a a huge amount of money
relative to training it on AWS or at any
other uh any other cloud provider um
even even and that assumes that we could
get gpus from
